You work as a Systems Administrator for your company. The company has a subscription to Microsoft 365. All users in your company have a Microsoft 365 E3 license.
All users use Microsoft Teams for collaboration.
Sales users in the company frequently invite potential customers to Microsoft Teams meetings. The potential customers do not have guest accounts.
Sales users report that the potential customers are unable to join the meetings.
You need to configure the system to enable the potential customers to join the meetings.
What should you do?

choices.D: Configure the Automatically admit users to Everyone in your organization setting in the global meeting policy.
choices.A: Enable the Anonymous users can join a meeting in the Meeting settings.
choices.B: Configure the Automatically admit users to Everyone setting in the global meeting policy.
choices.C: Enable the Allow guest access in Teams in the Org-wide settings.

discussion.content: A is correct.

Selected Answer: A
A. Enable the Anonymous users can join a meeting in the Meeting settings.

Enabling this setting allows users who are not signed in to a Microsoft account or not part of your organization to join meetings as guests, which is essential for potential customers who do not have guest accounts.

To meet the specified requirements, you’ll need two auto attendants. Let me explain why:

Office Hours Greeting: You can configure one auto attendant to handle calls during office hours (Monday to Friday, 09:00 to 17:00). This auto attendant will play the appropriate greeting and route calls accordingly.
Outside Office Hours, Weekends, and Holidays Greeting: For the remaining scenarios (outside office hours, weekends, and national holidays), you can set up a second auto attendant. This way, you’ll have a total of two unique greetings—one for office hours and another for non-office hours.
Remember that auto attendants allow callers to navigate a menu system and direct their calls to the right department, person, or other destinations within your organization1. Additionally, each auto attendant can have up to 15 authorized users2.

So, the correct answer is B. 2 auto attendants.

A is correct. It is a little bit tricky but you can create a Call queue which already plays a welcome greeting. You could us it as the "on-hours" greeting. Just add a specific resource account to the call queue. Then configure the greeting and choose 1 dummy user which is never online. So you can set the Presence-based routing to on. In the last step of the call queue setup you need to redirect calls to a Voice app which is the resource account you also assign the AA to. Then you need to configure the AA. The call flow greeting will be the "outside office hours" greeting. "Call flow for after hours" will be configured with weekend greetings and in the last step you configure the holidays within the AA config.

For sure nobody will configure it like this in the field but it is a solution which just requires just on AA for this setup.
